template.name: Template Exchange Server 2016
template.description:
MS Exchange Server 2016 template v0.1.1
LLD: - Databases (with PowerShell script)
All thresholds taken from this page: https://docs.microsoft.com/ru-ru/exchange/exchange-2013-performance-counters-exchange-2013-help

item.name: ActiveSync ping command pending
item.description: Shows the number of ping commands currently pending in the queue.

item.name: ActiveSync requests per second
item.description: Shows the number of HTTP requests received from the client via ASP.NET per second. Determines the current Exchange ActiveSync request rate. Used only to determine current user load.

item.name: ActiveSync sync commands per second
item.description: Shows the number of sync commands processed per second. Clients use this command to synchronize items within a folder.

item.name: Autodiscover requests per second
item.description: Shows the number of Autodiscover service requests processed each second. Determines current user load.

item.name: Availability Service availability requests per second
item.description: Shows the number of requests serviced per second. The request can be only for free/ busy information or include suggestions. One request may contain multiple mailboxes. Determines the rate at which Availability service requests are occurring.

item.name: OWA current unique users
item.description:
The number of unique active user sessions, so that users are only removed from this counter after they log off or their session times out. Determines current user load.
# There are many problems with that performance counter - it can starts to show huge numbers of connected users randomly. So trigger is disabled by default.

item.name: OWA requests per second
item.description: Shows the number of requests handled by Outlook Web App per second. Determines current user load.

item.name: MSExchangeWS requests per second
item.description: Shows the number of requests processed each second. Determines current user load.

item.name: Web Service Default Web Site Current Connections
item.description: Shows the current number of connections established to the Default website which corresponds to the number of connections hitting the Front End CAS server role. Determines current user load.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} database copy status
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Active Manager({#DB.LCNAME})\Database Copy Role Active"]
item_prototype.description: Is the database {#DB.NAME} copy active? 0 - passive 1 - active

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} database mounted state
item_prototype.description: Database {#DB.NAME} mounted state. 0 - not mounted 1 - mounted

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} page faults per second
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database(Information Store - {#DB.NAME})\Database Page Fault Stalls/sec",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}]
item_prototype.description: Indicates the rate of page faults that can't be serviced because there are no pages available for allocation from the database cache. If this counter is above 0, it's an indication that the MSExchange Database\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency is too high.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} log record stalls
item_prototype.description:
Indicates the number of log records that can't be added to the log buffers per second because the log buffers are full.
The average value should be below 10 per second. Spikes (maximum values) shouldn't be higher than 100 per second.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} log threads waiting
item_prototype.description:
Indicates the number of threads waiting to complete an update of the database by writing their data to the log.
The average value should be less than 10 threads waiting.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} active database read operations per second
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Database Reads (Attached)/sec",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}]
item_prototype.description: Shows the number of database read operations.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} active database read operations latency
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}]
item_prototype.description: Shows the average length of time, in milliseconds (ms), per database read operation. Should be less than 20ms on average.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} passive database read operation latency
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}]
item_prototype.description: Shows the average length of time, in ms, per passive database read operation. Should be less than 200ms on average.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} active database writes operations per second
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Database Writes (Attached)/sec",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}]
item_prototype.description: Number of database write operations per second for each attached database instance.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} active database writes operations latency
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}]
item_prototype.description: Shows the average length of time, in ms, per database write operation. Should be less than 50ms on average.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} passive database writes operation latency
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Database Writes (Recovery) Average Latency",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}]
item_prototype.description: Shows the average length of time, in ms, per passive database write operation. Should be less than the read latency for the same instance, as measured by the MSExchange Database ==> Instances(\*)\I/O Database Reads (Recovery) Average Latency counter.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} log writes operations per second
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Log Writes/sec",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}]
item_prototype.description: Shows the number of log writes per second.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} log writes operations latency
item_prototype.key: perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Log Writes Average Latency",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}]
item_prototype.description:
Shows the average length of time, in ms, per Log write operation. Should be less than 10ms on average.
If this counter is greater than 10, it's an indication that the MSExchange Database\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency is too high.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} active mailboxes count
item_prototype.description: Database {#DB.NAME} number of active mailboxes.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} database state
item_prototype.description: Database {#DB.NAME} state

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} RPC requests latency
item_prototype.description: RPC Latency average (msec) is the average latency in milliseconds of RPC requests per database. Average is calculated over all RPCs since exrpc32 was loaded. Should be less than 50ms at all times, with spikes less than 100ms.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} RPC requests per second
item_prototype.description: Shows the number of RPC operations per second for each database instance.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} RPC requests total
item_prototype.description: Indicates the overall RPC requests currently executing within the information store process. Should be below 70 at all times.

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} content index state
item_prototype.description: Database {#DB.NAME} content index state.

valuemap.name: Exchange Server 2016 Database Content Index States

item_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} edb file size
item_prototype.description: Database {#DB.NAME} edb file size.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} log records stalls too high: {ITEM.VALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: Stalled log records too high for database "{#DB.NAME}". The average value should be less than 10 threads waiting.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} log threads waiting too high: {ITEM.VALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: Log threads waiing count too high for database "{#DB.NAME}". The average value should be less than 10 threads waiting.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Exchange Server 2016:perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Log Writes Average Latency",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}].min(10m)}>10
trigger_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} log write latency too high: {ITEM.VALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: Log writes latency too high for database "{#DB.NAME}".

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Exchange Server 2016:perf_counter["\MSExchange Database(Information Store - {#DB.NAME})\Database Page Fault Stalls/sec",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}].max(5m)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} page faults too high
trigger_prototype.description: Too much page faults stalls for database "{#DB.NAME}". This counter should be 0 on production servers.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Exchange Server 2016:perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}].min(10m)}>20
trigger_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} read time latency too high: {ITEM.VALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: "{#DB.NAME}" average read time latency too high for 5 min.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} RPC Requests latancy too high: {ITEM.VALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: RPC Requests latancy too high for database "{#DB.NAME}".

trigger_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} RPC Requests too high: {ITEM.VALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: RPC Requests count for database "{#DB.NAME}" too high.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Exchange Server 2016:perf_counter["\MSExchange Database ==> Instances(Information Store - {#DB.NAME}/_Total)\I/O Database Writes (Attached) Average Latency",{$PERFCOUNTER_PERIOD}].avg(10m)}>50
trigger_prototype.name: {#DB.NAME} write time latency too high: {ITEM.VALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: "{#DB.NAME}" average write latency too high. In general, this latency should be less than the "MSExchange Database\I/O Database Reads (Attached) Average Latency" when battery-backed write caching is utilized.

item_prototype.name: Service {#SERVICE.NAME} status

trigger.name: Perfomance Counter for OWA Unique Users fucked up
trigger.description:
Счётчик "\MSExchange OWA\Current Unique Users" показывает дичь. Известный баг, iisreset помогает.
Триггер для наблюдения за поведением счётчика!

value_map.name: Exchange Server 2016 Database Content Index States
